author: John Woodrow Cox
title: The NFL writes on concussion awareness
text:
October 16 at 7:12 PM Steve Almond’s Sept. 13 Outlook essay, “ Hollywood’s version of the gridiron is just fantasy football ,” stated that the upcoming movie “Concussion” is “no doubt a headache for league executives.”
Some people may be unaware of the league’s efforts to better protect players and the positive effect these efforts have had for the game of football and beyond. We welcome any opportunity to talk about this important issue and the work that has been done.
The NFL’s player health and safety efforts include nearly 40 recent safety-related rules’ changes, groundbreaking and longtime investments in independent research to advance knowledge, equipment, diagnostics and treatment, and a well-established suite of programs to promote youth safety in football and across all sports.
These initiatives and others are producing real results in the NFL: Concussions are down 35 percent since 2012 , helmet-to-helmet hits are down 43 percent since 2012, concussions caused by helmet-to-helmet or shoulder-to-helmet hits were almost exactly halved in 2014 from two years before, and hits to defenseless players were down 68 percent from 2013 to 2014 .
There is more public attention paid now to player health and safety. For that we are grateful. Broadened and deepened awareness will serve only to provide a better and safer game for players and fans.
Jeff Miller , New York
The writer is senior vice president of health and safety policy for the National Football League.
